Description: First expansion for the 2016 big-hex reissue of the classic Advanced Tobruk wargame, including two pages of additional rules (Battlefield Walkaround), eight scenarios from June to December 1940, some additional Italian and British vehicle counters (ATS North Africa Expansion AFVs 2016_1940), a couple of pages of terrain overlays (wire, encampment and depots) and another two pages of vehicle cards.

Name: Likes
Description:
A party game where you and your friends will create fake online dating profiles.

Each round, one of the players is the judge and chooses a profile picture from the deck. Each other player then selects a card from their hand to create a memorable, intriguing, or hilarious dating profile.

The judge chooses their favorite and rewards the creator of the profile with a "Like".
 At the end of the game, players choose the "best" profile and use their "Likes" to vote on which player is most likely to date them. Whether that makes you the "winner" depends on the profile you decided was best.

Name: Merry Dissmas
Description: A rotating Diss-Master reads a card out loud to the group (for example: Who's the worst gift-giver? The chronic over-sharer? The pickiest eater?). Everyone else writes down their answer on their dry-erase boards, and then it's up to the Diss-Master to pick their favorite answer— after reading all the responses out loud, of course!

Name: La Casa de Papel: Behind the mask
Description:
The Netflix TV series that captivated millions of viewers has just become an exciting board game so you can experience the emotions and vicissitudes of the most famous band of thieves of all time.
 The game contains: a layout board of the Spanish Mint, 5 screens for hiding your notes from opponents, 1 pad of sheets for jotting down clues, 5 hostage pawns and 8 robber tiles.
 With the 44 cards in the game, the players/detectives must discover the identities of the 8 robbers, jotting down the Clues, Confidential Information and Characteristics emerging during the game.
 A deduction game in which you must work to reveal the identities of the thieves just like real detectives!
 A game that never ceases to amaze match after match, engaging everyone, not only fans of the series, in a fascinating, in-depth and first-hand investigation through a unique recreational experience.

Each turn the professor will call the police and you can reach a different room in the Mint. Here you can check a number of clue depending on the turn you are playing but the thief will be stressed by you and if they go "out of control" they will modify the quantity of the symbols in the room.

To deduct the identity of the wight thieves you'll need to understand which of the three symbols is the most present in each room.

Name: Memoroute
Description:
Memoroute is a memory game which moles compete to open new underground paths. Unlike other memory games, you don't take two matching tiles, instead, your mole moves to a hole next to the matching tile that you opened secondly. Most of the times, you have to match several tile sets (and move your mole) until your mole finally reaches to a hole you are to connect.

On your turn, you select one of the face-down flower tiles adjacent to your mole pawn and flip it to the flower side, and then select another face-down flower tile from anywhere on the board. If the two tiles match, move your mole next to one of the holes adjacent to the second tile.

You keep having your turn until you fail to find two matching tiles. And in anytime during your turn, if your mole gets to a hole indicated on your mission card, you flip that card and continue your turn.

When you fail, you reset the game board by flipping all the opened tile and pass your turn.  When a player flips all four mission cards, the player wins!

Moles, moles! Find the holes and stick the poles!

Name: The Malinsay Massacre
Description:
Crime Dossier 3 of a 4 book set that was an early progenitor of the modern mystery suspect / cold case tabletop games.

The Earl of Malinsay is dead, and ruin comes to an ancient family. Did the valet really murder his master, or did the mysterious foreigner send poisoned sweets to Viscount Raeburn? Whose handwriting is on the label and who put arsenic in the peppermints? Is the beautiful Countess conspiring with her lover or is the secret of the Malinsays hidden in the past?

Name: My Brand
Description:
The personal branding game, MY BRAND, is developed based on the 5-personality type of 'CEO Brand Big 5'. This theory is based on the "Brand Personality Big 5", developed by Professor Jennifer Aaker of Standford University.

Players become brand managers, and through three consecutive games that they will play, they will help others and themselves to learn about their current brands and the brands that they are to persue.

Game 1
Each player is dealt with 8 brand cards. 
Pick a card from the hand and introduce themselves using the brand card.
Players vote two players who presented the best.
Take the card and make your personal 'Brand Archive' pile.

Game 2 
Each player is dealt with 8 brand cards. 
Pick two card from the hand and open them on the table. 
Then players tell stories about the strengths they have. 
The other players offer each narrator a card from their hands.
The narrator takes two cards among them. 
Send those two cards along with two other cards you previously places on the table to your 'Brand Archive'.

Game 3
Each player is dealt with 8 brand cards. 
Players take turn become a presenter. The presenter opens a Question card. 
Question cards have questions like: 
'What is the cover of your autobiography that you've published 20 years later like?'
'What is the feed you are uploading, 5 years later, as a social media influencer like?
All players place a card face-down. The presenter gather the cards from the other players and add more card from the deck to make a total of 7 Brand cards. Shuffle them and open those cards in a single line. 
Players secretly select two cards they think most accurately represent the presenter related to the question. 
Then place tokens on those two cards. If more than two players selected the same cards, those players each gain points as many as the number of tokens on it. 
Sent three cards which have the most vote along with your own card to your 'Brand Archive.'

Players gain points as they play each game, they get points from the vote they get and the cards selected by other players, etc. Whoever has the highest score after three games becomes the best brand manager and wins the game.

After the game, you can examine and draw your brand in graph at the back of your sheet. 
It will visually tell you your current brand and the brand to pursue.

Name: Sea Battle Agrisha
Description:
Sea Battle Agrisha is a 2-player drafting and worker placement game using similar mechanics as Agrisha.  Players draw resource dice from a bag, roll them, draft them, and then take actions, such as placing or removing Sway, to secure control of the ships involved in the fight.

Unlike Agrisha, the players in Sea Battle Agrisha have asymmetrical starting positions.  Both players have a Captain and First Mate who have unique special abilities.  Additionally, both players control a flagship, which are also not identical.

There are 2 pages to print, and you will need a number of dice and tokens (beads, cubes, or whatnot) to play.

—description from the designer

Name: Wild West Exodus: Showdown at Retribution
Description:
Wild West Exodus is a dynamic, fast-paced tabletop miniatures game pitting a cast of heroic characters against each other in a brutal world - very much a twisted reflection of our own. In the twilight years of the Nineteenth Century, mankind is perched upon a new age of discovery and enlightenment.

However, humanity’s greed and ambition have created a Dystopian Age where nations clash and the threat of war forever lingers. We must remember that all is not lost. In Wild West Exodus the bravery and actions of individuals on the frontier can still forge legends and change the world.

Showdown at Retribution is a two-player starter set designed to give you a comprehensive introduction to the savage Wild West in the Dystopian Age. Containing dozens of fantastically detailed Warcradle miniatures, the full third edition rulebook, quick start guide to help you get going straight away and much more - this hefty boxed set is an easy way to explore the game and start your hobby adventure.

—description from the publisher

Name: Skilled: Das Bike Spiel
Description:
A game to experience the world of cycling and to explore the cycling world of Austria.
A combination of tactics and concentration as well as muscle power provides the necessary variety to win the game and to become the best biker who feels just as comfortable on trails as on racing bike courses.

The aim of the game is to “cycle” 500 points on the points table.
The biker (player) who does this first is declared the winner.
The last biker to reach the finish invites the winner to a bike ride. :-)
The points can be collected on the bike routes on the game board in the individual bike regions of austria, when passing the starting fields and through clever tactics with the playing cards.

Name: White Elephant: A Gift Exchange
Description:
White Elephant is a negotiation game featuring a gift economy system. In White Elephant, you pass gifts around and collect the most items you can. Be the one who scores the most items in your group of friends.

The deck of gifts contains an assortment of cards with one, two, or three gifts, among six different types. The game starts by randomly determining play order by shuffling and dealing out the player aid cards, which have the numbers one through six on the back. The play order stays the same throughout play. Players create two score sheets, one for each of the left and right hand neighbors at the table. At the end of the game, each player will receive points for the number of gifts shown on the cards they collect for each of the scoring categories on the score sheet. Before play, decide whether the play will be "generous" or "greedy."

Beginning with the first player and proceeding in order, turn gifts face-up from the top of the draw pile until there are six or more gift icons showing. Choose who will get which cards. In "generous" mode, you must give away all but one card (but may give away all of them). In "greedy" mode, you must give away at least one card (but may give away as many more as you like, up to all of them). Players negotiate and make suggestions about who should get which cards, but ultimately, the current player decides. You cannot refuse a gift.

At the end of the round, count up the number of each kind of icon, and score points for each according to how your neighbors filled out the two score sheets they passed to you, except that you don't score any points for the type of icon you collected the most.

Name: No More Valentine: Operation Squarepeg
Description:
A small postcard game on the landing operations by the US and New Zealand forces on Nissan Island, the Green Islands, on February 15, 1944 (operation Squarepeg).

The game features a standard "I go-you go" mechanics but with unlimited movement subject to fatigue (the more you move, the higher the possibility of being fatigued). The NZ player must conquer the objective hex or eliminate all Japanese units in 5 turns; otherwise, the Japanese player wins.

Name: Fantastic Pop Trivia: Questions from Every Decade
Description:
Pop Trivia game comes with all you need for a trivia challenge of epic proportions! Simply slip off the lid, pull out a card, roll the die and off you go!

Featuring questions from the last six decades, Pop Trivia covers every aspect of popular culture from flares to feng shui, Beatlemania to breakdancing...as well as questions on the music we all enjoy too!

Pop Trivia is the ideal game for those who remember the good old days...with a smile!

—description from the back of the box

Name: Iwoká: La Tierra sin Mal
Description:
The game is called Iwoká: La Tierra sin Mal (The land without evil). It is played on the space of a board, between two players: one will be the Tupi-Guarani aboriginal people, and the other the viceroy with his army. But, while the game is played, the competitors -due to the characteristics of entertainment- will be invited to walk the path of historical knowledge; they will be able to know the circumstances of the time; the rituals, legends and cosmogonies of the aborigines; They will be able to delve into the war iconography of the time, the weapons and ships of the conquerors, their war tactics, etc. And, also, some continental geography.

Two players or teams can play the Iwoká from the age of 9. One will be the Tupi-Guarani people, and the other will be the viceroy and his army. It is played with green and brown chips, in circular movements. On the board the most important place is the center called Arete (the promised land of the aboriginal people). The viceroy is occupying this sacred place: his objective will be to leave through four paths or exit points, from the center to the outside of the board, and flee by ship with the stolen riches. In the escape, he will be protected by his army.

The Tupi-Guarani, who are around the Arete, have the mission of preventing the viceroy and his army from escaping with his riches. How do they prevent the flight of the conquerors? Enclosing them with tokens. The army can be "eaten" with the tokens and eliminated, but the viceroy must be locked up with the tokens.

The invaders win if the viceroy reaches any of the four starting squares, and flee with the riches. The natives win if the viceroy is trapped between tiles.

Name: Pyramiland
Description:
Your challenge in Pyramiland is to rid yourself of the balls in your collection first.

To set up, place up to sixty pegs in the holes of the wooden game board to create the field of play, and give each player the same number of wooden balls. On a turn, you place a ball on the playing area, then you can play again if you can place a ball so that it touches the ball just placed while also being on a higher level. You can continue to take extra turns so long as you can do this.

When you place on the lowest level, your ball must be supported by four wooden pegs. On the second level and higher, your ball just needs to be supported by other balls, but due to the layout of the pegs, not all of the balls will be in identical rows, so you likely won't have a clean, regular-shaped pyramid as you build to higher levels.

Whoever places their final ball first wins. If a player cannot place a ball or knocks a ball from the pyramid, including one just placed, the game ends, that player loses, and whoever has the fewest balls remaining wins.

Name: Civilisations
Description:
Civilisations is a card game about building competing ancient civilisations over three Ages 
Each Age has a different deck of cards. At the start of the game the first Age is divided into a number of hands equal to the number of players plus an extra hand which is set aside.
The set aside hand means that the card mix if different for each game, creating a strong replay value.
Each player then chooses a card from their hand and these cards are played simultaneously, paid for with Gold from your civilisations treasury.
Most cards have Military and/or Culture values and all cards have a special effect. When the card is played the special effect is resolved. These effects do things like enhancing other cards already in play, scoring extra points for certain cards, making certain types of cards cheaper to buy, removing or stealing cards from opponents and a host of other things to.
Some special effects are triggered by circumstances and if not triggered when played will wait until a later turn when their trigger condition is met.
Cards which target other players usually target a random card and/or a random player to prevent players ganging up one someone and ruining their fun.
After playing a card, hands are passed round the table clockwise, giving you new options and choices to make.
Once each player has played 6 cards the Age ends and the player with the card with the highest single Military score gains a Colonisation culture bonus and then players may choose to declare War on each other. Winning a war gets you a small amount of gold but, more importantly, destroys a random card from your opponent.
At the end of the third Age Culture scores are added up to find out who won.
The game was written with the following in mind:

     A game should take 1-2 hours (my attention span now is about 2 hours.. age is great :)
     The game can be played on a card or kitchen table
     Set-up and take down time for a game is less than 5 minutes
     You don't need to refer to the rulebook in play, everything you need to know is on the cards (e.g. card abilities are clearly explained in plain english)
     There is a degree of randomness which stops players ganging up on other players
     The game allows direct (war and espionage) and indirect competition (choosing cards which you know your opponent would like)
     No one gets "knocked out" or falls so far behind as not to be able to win. Games are nearly always very close.
     Every decision is interesting and important, you will nearly always want to play more than one of the cards in your hand and have to choose which very carefully
     Choosing cards which interact with each other in positive ways is critical to victory, but the swapping of hands requires some careful forethought on what cards to play and when and also allows you to mess with your opponents by playing cards they want!
     Each game is unique and you have to adapt to the cards you are given


The core game focuses on the region around the Mediterranean sea and Carthage, the Celts, Greece, Rome, Persia and Egypt as playable civilisations.

—description from the designer

Name: The 50 States Game
Description:
How well do you really know the USA? This game will vastly improve your knowledge while introducing the thrill of competition and a great deal of fun between friends and family.

Each player gets two state sheets - five states per sheet. The first player that fills ONE sheet wins the game. Player gets cards by either competing with facts (Area, Population, Highest point, Avg. temperatre) or either wining challenges. Challenge can be called by player that's on turn and holding a weak card - lower fact values and is decided by dice roll.

Name: Coopolis
Description:
Coopolis, the game of cooperatives is the result of our exploration of dynamic and innovative educational resources and has been declared by the Legislature of the Autonomous City of Buenos Aires of Interest in matters of Cooperativism and Education, for its contributions to the dissemination of the values â€‹â€‹of cooperation, solidarity and collective work (Declaration no. 148-2014 / File 1043-D-2014).

Coopolis is a creative and dynamic educational game designed to introduce the growing cooperative economy. In Coopolis, players must work together to found and run a democratic company. To develop as individuals and to strive for the success of their cooperative, they must make decisions, while putting their teamwork skills to the test through familiar and entertaining games such as "mimic it", "taboo" and "draw it". Yes you can". This is an exciting game of skill and solidarity, where everyone wins or everyone loses. By playing Coopolis, we learn about the unique benefits, challenges, and how the co-op world works.

—description from the publisher

Name: Warmis: Mujeres en Lucha
Description:
This game that has the purpose of making visible and spreading the leading role that Latin American women have had in the construction of a different world, in the struggle to defend the rights of the oppressed peoples and classes.

Transforming in each of its steps the history of the entire continent, breaking barriers, in no hurry to lose calm until patriarchy and capitalism fall.

It is three games in one, or three modes to play with the same cards.

The first mode "Allies", each player must summon Allies to add more voices and defeat the Patriarchy.

The deck of cards is taken and they will be revealed one at a time.

On their turn, each player can choose to take refuge with their Allies, or stay in the streets to gather more voices, but be careful, since the same deck can leave Violence cards, which will stop us in the fight for freedom.

Violence cards include, Repression, Disappearance, Indifference, Capitalism, and Patriarchy. If one of these cards appears, we will be at risk, but we can continue fighting, if a second card appears, we will lose all the Allies that we had gathered that round.

The second mode "United" is a very dynamic game in real time, where we will try to collect all the cards of the same fighter as quickly as possible, to get all the characteristics of each one, and to put an end to the disinformation of their stories. .

We will have 7 different cards in our hands, and we will have to exchange cards with other players, with the only limitation that all the cards delivered must be from the same Fighter. The player who manages to collect the 7 cards of the same Fighter first, will be the winner.

Finally, the third modality "Abya Yala", is a cooperative game where we will try to reconstruct the story. For which we will have to put together a timeline ordering from smallest to largest the year in which the women who have fought to defend the rights of our peoples throughout the continent were born.

But with a twist, since we will play with our cards upside down, so that we can only see the back of our cards, but we can see all the cards in hand of our partners.

In turn, we will have to give clues to the other players about the cards in their hand, and thus be able, together, to put together the correct time lines.

A lot of memory, a lot of commitment, in a beautifully illustrated game, with great quality components, which will help us become aware and build knowledge for the construction of a different, fairer and more inclusive society.
